Less work. That's basically it.

With cash, you just categorize bank transactions as they come in. No bills to enter upfront, no extra step.

[message_id: 5335]

**Cash basis** is simpler — you only care about money when it moves. Good for small businesses, freelancers. Easy to understand: money came in, money went out.

**Accrual basis** matches revenue with ...

📨 [Telegram Charlie Maréchal id:8413738428 +38s 2026-02-07 16:27 EST] whats the reason for these two systems?
[message_id: 5333]

Yes. When you create a bill in QB, you assign it to a vendor (the performer). When you pay that bill, QB tracks the payment against that vendor for 1099 reporting — same as now.

The only difference i...

- COGS recorded: **$81K** ← this is actually performer pay from **December's** work
- Real January performer costs are probably sitting ...

- Januar...

With accrual, when you create a **bill** (not just pay someone), QB records the expense immediately — even before you pay it.

So the flow would be:

**End of January:** You create bills in QB for eac...

Exactly. If you're on **cash basis** accounting (QB default), expenses only show up when the money leaves your account. So January's P&L looks great because performer pay for January work doesn't hit ...
